body: The error message of course needs some work, but it's a very clever trick that you are pulling here. I think this is a very good prototype for solving the issue.

I'm +0 on this - the issue in #6365 was related to browser cache - which is tricky. It's not clear to me under which circumstances this would fail to detect a problem. As implemented right now, it seems the error is displayed all the time, even if I take out the `1/0` line. 

To help facilitate the conversation, here's a screenshot of the warning. 
![2014-08-27-092253_1282x490_scrot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/118211/4063440/b03f3f6a-2e07-11e4-8801-66c0fb78eeae.png)

Stylistically, I think it shouldn't take up so much vertical space (and actually should probably overlay over the top  of the dashboard, with a style of `position: absolute;`)

Certainly it makes sense to display something like this when something as catastrophic as JQuery failing to load happens, but do we want to do the same if there's a problem with `custom.js`?

The real problem in #6365 stemmed from the fact that we moved some js components around, and the browser was using cached javascript which referred to the old locations.  One approach to notifying users of that problem would be: instead of 404ing the old location, instead serve javascript that adds such a message to the page. Another alternative would be to keep track of components as we move them around and have routing rules that would issue a 301 Moved Permanently in those cases.

> I'm +0 on this - the issue in #6365 was related to browser cache - which is
> tricky.

But it's important to solve it, because you are going to loose people on
it.

> As implemented right now, it seems the error is displayed all the time,
> even if I take out the 1/0 line.

Yes. Matthias saw this problem this afternoon. Indeed, the proposed
solution is not yet the right one. However, it is going in the right
direction.

> As implemented right now, it seems the error is displayed all the time, even if I take out the 1/0 line.

Yes, on the dashboard, not on the  notebook (proof of concept you know)... 

> Stylistically, I think it shouldn't take up so much vertical space (and actually should probably overlay over the top of the dashboard, with a style of position: absolute;)
> 
> Certainly it makes sense to display something like this when something as catastrophic as JQuery failing to load happens, but do we want to do the same if there's a problem with custom.js?

Yes, style is bad, but that was not the point of the PR. 
Issues you cannot distinguish failing to loa from custom.js than jquery faillure. 

404 or 301 ing will not help as the js just display a message in the console and you cannot catch that. 

Also the issues was not **only** caches. The goal he is to find a way to show something to the user that give some hints of what to do if there is a problem in js loading:

```
- Did you `pip install ipython[notebook]` otherwise you won't get JS
- Did you try to force-refresh your browser ? 
- Please open the developpement console and look if you have error
```

There is nothing more annoying that having a fucking white page and don't even know what to do. 
Even Gael and I, which are I think quite good user had a hard time figuring out why it was not working. 

We already have a `<noscript>` that show a message if js is disable, the question do we at least try to show something if js crash ?

Ok, better style and message. From the dev meeting I think I have strong pushback unless we can have a real description of case where this is usefull. IMHO, the use-case is upgrade where the js file of IPython X.y might have  been cached  new version don't load. 
![capture d ecran 2014-09-03 a 06 31 43](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335567/4134660/c3c4dc2c-336e-11e4-957f-635b10a8a7e1.png)
We decided to close this issue in favor of trying to fix the underlying issues with caching, JS and require.js. Posting comment in the issue @GaelVaroquaux opened about this.
